Protect your family's health with accurate, EPA-certified radon testing from certified professionals

What is Radon and Why Should You Care?

Radon is a colorless, odorless radioactive gas that occurs naturally when uranium in soil, rock, and water breaks down. It's the second leading cause of lung cancer in the United States, responsible for about 21,000 deaths each year according to the EPA and Surgeon General.

The scary part? You can't see, smell, or taste radon. The only way to know if your home has dangerous radon levels is through professional testing. That's where Lifetime Home Services comes in.

  • 1 in 15 homes in the US has elevated radon levels

  • Children are at higher risk due to faster breathing rates

How Does Radon Enter Your Home?

Think of your home like a vacuum cleaner. As air moves through your house, it creates slight pressure differences that can pull radon gas up from the soil through:

  • Foundation cracks - Even hairline cracks can let radon in
  • Floor drains - Especially in basements and crawl spaces
  • Sump pump pits - Open connections to soil
  • Construction joints - Where walls meet floors
  • Gaps around pipes - Utility penetrations through foundation
  • Well water - Can release radon when used (less common)

Types of Radon Testing We Offer

Short-Term Testing (48-96 hours)

Best for: Quick results, real estate transactions, initial screening

  • Fastest way to get radon levels
  • Uses activated charcoal or electret ion chambers
  • Perfect for home sales/purchases
  • Results available within 1-2 weeks

Long-Term Testing (90+ days)

Best for: Most accurate annual average, comprehensive assessment

  • Accounts for seasonal variations
  • Uses alpha track detectors
  • Most accurate representation of yearly exposure
  • Recommended by EPA for final decisions

Continuous Monitoring

Best for: Real-time data, post-mitigation verification

  • Hour-by-hour radon level tracking
  • Immediate results and trends
  • Detects tampering or unusual conditions
  • Perfect for mitigation system verification

Understanding Your Radon Test Results

Radon is measured in picocuries per liter (pCi/L). Here's what your numbers mean:

Below 2 pCi/L

Low Risk: No action needed, but consider retesting every 2-5 years

2-4 pCi/L

Moderate Risk: EPA recommends considering mitigation, especially for long-term exposure

4+ pCi/L

Action Required: EPA strongly recommends mitigation. Risk equivalent to smoking 8+ cigarettes daily

20+ pCi/L

Urgent Action: Immediate mitigation needed. Risk equivalent to smoking 2+ packs daily

Frequently Asked Questions

How long does radon testing take?

Short-term tests run 48-96 hours, long-term tests run 90+ days. We'll help you choose the right option based on your timeline and needs.

Do I need to do anything to prepare for testing?

Yes! Keep windows and doors closed 12 hours before and during testing (except for normal entry/exit). Don't run fans or air conditioning systems that bring in outside air.

Where should radon testing be done?

Testing should be done in the lowest livable level of your home - typically the basement or first floor if there's no basement. We test in rooms you actually use, not storage areas.

What if my radon levels are high?

Don't panic! High radon levels can be reduced with proper mitigation systems. We'll explain your options and can install a mitigation system if needed.

How much does radon testing cost?

Our testing services start at $150 for short-term testing. Contact us for a free quote based on your specific needs and home size.

Should I test if I'm buying/selling a home?

Absolutely! Many real estate contracts include radon testing contingencies. We can work with your timeline to ensure smooth transactions.

When Should You Test for Radon?

The EPA recommends testing your home for radon, but certain situations make testing especially important:

  • Buying or selling a home - Protect your investment and family
  • After major renovations - Construction can change radon pathways
  • Every 2-5 years - Radon levels can change over time
  • If neighbors have high levels - Geology affects entire neighborhoods
  • Before finishing a basement - Know your levels before creating living space
  • After installing HVAC systems - New systems can affect air pressure
